reviewText: The photography was excellent, the setting and characters seemed true to my image of my scottish ancestry, but the storyline was difficult for me because of my age-related (91 yrs) hearing impairment and the dvd did not provide subtitles as I viewed it on Kindle Fiire--a serious lack--so much so that I watched only about 10 minutes,then gave up.

reviewText: Set in Scotland, the lovely scenery and gentle wit of this old classic movie will leave you longing for the good old days - or running for your glucose monitor!  If you enjoy beautiful, rustic settings and a film that leaves you happy that you visited a while, this is a good choice for you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maurice Walsh, long endeared to readers for Irish classic The Quiet Man, also wrote an endearing tale set in the Scottish Highlands:  TROUBLE IN THE GLEN.For some reason, the brilliant, funny, and endearing TROUBLE has largely been lost to time, rarely carried by video houses and not out on DVD.  If you get a VHS copy, you'll have to endure scratchy sound and bad color--but it's well-worth it.Orson Welles is a belligerent Argentine descendent of Highland lairds, returned to take up the title, and hating every second of it.  His tirade against bagpipes and the Scottish brogue at the beginning is worth the price of this tape!  Although he's a bit silly made up to look like a tanned Scotsman, his performance in right on key!As Welles cracks down on locals to defend his property rights, he comes into conflict with burly Victor McLaglen, head of a clan of tinks, and with Forrest Tucker, a US airman, returned to see a handicapped girl he knew from the war years.No, there's no brawl scene to match QUIET MAN, nor a soundtrack that engaging, but there's also no glossing over of life in the rural Celtic country.A witty, touching and refreshing film, TROUBLE is one you'll watch again and again.
summary: Lost Sister of the Quiet Man
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a delightful film I first saw on b/w TV in the 50's. It is a charming story. A real movie movie. The only mistake is the casting of Orson Wells as a Scottish laird. He is his usually urbane and witty self, but he sticks out like a sore thumb/
summary: Almost as good as "The Quiet Man"
